title.narrative: CROSS-SECTORAL Communication for Development (C4D)

description.narrative: By end 2022, UNICEF staff and partners have the appropriate tools, guidance and resources to plan, implement, coordinate and effectively monitor the implementation of multisectoral Communication for Development (C4D) strategies including in emergency response., which contributes to Communication And Advocacy, Cross-Sectoral - Human Rights, Cross-Sectoral - Other Programme Areas, Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change, Cross-Sectoral - Social And Behaviour Change (Covid). UNICEF aims to achieve this through Advocacy And Communications, Advocacy And Public Engagement, Community Engagement, Social And Behaviour Change, Evaluations, Research And Data, Systems Strengthening And Institution Building. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By the end of 2022, the country programme is effectively designed, coordinated, managed and supported to meet quality programming standards to achieve the best results for children in Chad.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By end 2022, UNICEF staff and partners have the appropriate tools, guidance and resources to plan, implement, coordinate andeffectively monitor the implementation of multisectoral C4D strategies including in emergency response.

description.narrative: In 2021, C4D focused on mainstreaming behavioural and social change at downstream and upstream levels through interventions focused on both the regular programme and emergencies with an emphasis on COVID-19 pandemic response. Upstream behaviours and social norms programme/policy were developed through the internal social and behaviour change (SBC) strategy development. Community engagement platforms received substantial support to meet quality standards across all development priorities. In total, 1,832,352 people (366% of the annual target) were reached by SBC strategies, and 3,149,190 people (46.5% of annual target) on prevention and access to COVID-19 services, including COVID-19 vaccination. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:21/01/2022
